text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam has just finished a three-day official friendship visit to Havana, which was on the invitation of his Cuban counterpart, Roberto Robaina.

-- Typhoon Williee hit the coastal district of Nghi Xuan in the central province of Ha Tinh, about 300 km (188 miles) south of Hanoi, late on Sunday night. First reports suggested that trees had been uprooted and houses had lost their roofs.
-- The official Vietnam News Agency has opened a Washington bureau.
-- A delegation from the Australian House of Representatives, led by Speaker Bob Halverson, arrived in Hanoi on Sunday to begin a five-day visit to Vietnam.
-- Vietnam is expected to export 24,000 tonnes of cashew nuts worth over $100 million this year, making it the world's third largest exporter of cashews after India and Brazil. - - - -
-- Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam confirmed Vietnam's whole-hearted support for Cuba's revolution during a meeting with Cuban President Fidel Castro in Havana last week.
-- Vietnam launched a "Campaign to Clean the World" in the central provinces of Nam Ha and Quang Nam-Da Nang and Ho Chi Minh city on Sunday with support from the Australian Embassy in Vietnam.
-- Vice Minister of Trade Ta Ca estimated that Vietnam will export $900 million worth of garments and textiles in 1996. - - - -
-- Tropical storm Willie caused torrential rain and strong winds in the central provinces of Ha Tinh, Nghe An and Quang Binh.
-- Eighty-two percent of the country's summer-autumn rice crop has now been harvested. - - - -
